agenda_items.title: Oral Communications
agenda_items.summary: The commission received no cards or phone calls on hold.

agenda_items.title: Recruitment and Examination Report
agenda_items.summary: Ms. Adams presented the regular recruitment and examination status report, noting 36 open recruitments and identifying the various stages of examination and selection. She indicated the report was for note and file, and she was available for questions.

agenda_items.title: Eligible Lists Established
agenda_items.summary: Ms. Adams presented the regular report, including all eligible lists established since the last meeting in May. The report included the total number of applications and individuals who advanced through the examination processes. Twelve lists were established, seven open to the public, four promotional, and one open and promotional. She indicated this was a note and file item, but she was available for questions.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Magravian
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Magravian reviewed the administrative assistant position, noting the high number of applicants (261) compared to the small number placed on the eligibility list (6). She commended the city for its hard work in finding those six qualified candidates given the high number of applicants, no-shows, and those not passing, which shows the effort put into hiring. She concluded by stating that the numbers show how much effort goes into hiring someone, expressing that even though it looks like there are many people available on the outset, you only find six, so she wanted to express that it’s a ‘good job, everyone.’

agenda_items.title: Introduction of Commissioner Jinanian
agenda_items.summary: Chair Hatamian formally introduced Commissioner Jinanian to the Civil Service Commission, indicating that Commissioner Jinanian would be involved in the discussions for Item 6. The Chair then noted that they would take item 8 out of order, following a comment from the staff.

agenda_items.title: Civil Service Commission Staff Comments
agenda_items.summary: There were no comments before the introduction of Commissioner Jinanian.

agenda_items.title: Formal Introduction of Commissioner Jinanian
agenda_items.summary: Chair Hatamian introduced Commissioner Jinanian, mentioning a review of his resume submitted to the city and noting his extensive experience in the government and private sectors. He welcomed him and passed it to Commissioner Jinanian for a formal introduction to the audience.

agenda_items.title: Commissioner Jinanian Introduction
agenda_items.summary: Commissioner Jinanian introduced himself as a 35-plus-year resident of Glendale, raising three young boys with his wife. He serves as the Director of Global Government Affairs for LAM Research Corporation, a semiconductor equipment maker, and as the Vice Chair of the LA County Small Business Commission. Previously, he worked on Capitol Hill for about 10 years, handling business policy and the US Chamber of Commerce, where he did the same. He expressed excitement about working with the commission and joked that he hopes he won’t get billed by any of the attorneys for his time.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Chair Hatamian
commissioner_comments.comment: Chair Hatamian welcomed Commissioner Jinanian, highlighting the commission's collaborative nature. He emphasized that diverse backgrounds are valuable, even outside of the legal field, and appreciated Commissioner Jinanian’s presence.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Magravian
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Magravian welcomed Commissioner Jinanian, stating looking forward to very much working with him.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Reen
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Reen welcomed Commissioner Jinanian to the board.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Chair Hatamian
commissioner_comments.comment: Chair Hatamian mentioned that, if it wasn't for the Council, Ms. Lucy Varpetian, he would have gone off of the agenda, and that she is always there to help. The chair expressed that he has known Lucy for a long time, and that she is there to help in any communication that is needed, making sure they stay aligned with all of the different duties and obligations that they have as commissioners.

agenda_items.title: Job Bulletin for Approval - Police Lieutenant
agenda_items.summary: Ms. Adams presented the Police Lieutenant job bulletin for approval, as Civil Service Rule 4 Section 3C requires Commission approval prior to posting for sworn promotional recruitments. The job bulletin aligns with the existing Police Lieutenant class specification, with some modifications requested by police management. A key addition is designating the Supervisory Leadership Institute (SLI) as a highly desirable qualification, but not required. Additional refinements were made to better articulate the skills, knowledge, and abilities expected for this management-level position. The selection process will mirror previous recruitments, including application evaluation, professional panel interview with a tactical component, and a community internal panel interview. With approval, the job bulletin will be posted from June 30th through July 14th, 2025. Examinations are tentatively scheduled for the week of August 18th, 2025. At the police department's request and consistent with Civil Service Rule 4 Section 17, the eligibility list from this recruitment will be valid for one year. The Glendale Management Association has reviewed the job bulletin and expressed no concerns. The recommendation is for the Commission to approve the proposed job bulletin for Police Lieutenant as submitted. A human resources analyst and a representative from police management are present to answer questions.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Magravian
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Magravian voiced strong approval for the additions to the job description, noting they strengthen the job duties and are well-aligned with the responsibilities of a Lieutenant. She noted she looked at the position from every direction and that she had nothing to say that she would recommend adding or changing, further voicing that she really likes the position the way it's written.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Reen
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Reen asked whether it makes sense to update the classification if there are changes, even if they are not major.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Ms. Adams
commissioner_comments.comment: Ms. Adams responded that there is no need to change the class specification tonight. She mentioned that the city is undergoing a top-to-bottom review of all class specifications, led by a city resource specialist. Over the next 12 months, the Commission will likely see hundreds of updated class specifications, including those from the police department, at some point.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Reen
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Reen stated that it is good practice to ensure that the bulletin matches the classification as closely as possible, but acknowledged that it's not essential in this instance. Additionally, he asked how the members of the interview panels are selected, inquiring if some are members of law enforcement from other jurisdictions and some are members of the community.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Ms. Adams
commissioner_comments.comment: Ms. Adams responded that they work closely with the Chief of Police and take his recommendations. They also listen to the input of the City Manager, particularly when selecting members from the public to place on a panel. HR then reaches out to those who have been recommended to determine their availability, and that's how they assemble the panels.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Reen
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Reen clarified that the department finds people to invite and that someone can not just invite themself.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Ms. Adams
commissioner_comments.comment: Ms. Adams confirmed that the interviews are by invitation only.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Chair Hatamian
commissioner_comments.comment: Chair Hatamian asked for clarification on the procedure after class specifications and changes are presented to the commission. If the commission makes any changes to those class specs, does it then go back to the union for approval, given that the union approves the class specs before they come here? If we make changes, does it go back to them, or do you look for work impact and then take it back to them?

commissioner_comments.speaker: Ms. Adams
commissioner_comments.comment: Ms. Adams responded that they only take it back to the unions if the recommended edits are substantial. If they are minor, grammatical, or more clearly state the essential functions, they don't take that information back. However, if it's substantial and it's going to change the requirements to compete or the design of the examination, then yes, they would have to go back and meet and confer with the union again.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Commissioner Naravian
commissioner_comments.comment: Commissioner Naravian asked for assurance that all eligible sergeants have access to the Supervisory Leadership Institute.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Captain Robert Williams
commissioner_comments.comment: Captain Robert Williams responded that every sergeant is eligible to take the Supervisory Leadership Institute after their one-year probation. He mentioned that the course spans over eight months, making it a big commitment, and they therefore do not make it mandatory. He noted that SLI is highly desirable, and all their sergeants know it and that the Supervisory Leadership Institute is well-known and considered esteemed in California, with agencies from Southern California to Northern California participating.

agenda_items.title: Reports and Information: Employee Job Performance Evaluations Past Due Aging Report
agenda_items.summary: Ms. Adams presented an informational report on performance evaluations and the return status for the City of Glendale's employees. She noted that the response rate is very good and that there are no evaluations on the second notice list. She indicated that this was a note and file item, but she was available for questions.

commissioner_comments.speaker: Chair Hatamian
commissioner_comments.comment: Chair Hatamian commended the staff for achieving zero evaluations on the second notice list, which he stated is challenging in the government sector. He noted that in large organizations, like the Sheriff's Department (18,500 people) and the Department of Mental Health (4,500 people), it is difficult to achieve, so he expressed that the city’s ability to achieve that zero number is pretty amazing.
